DIV1.P: A MEMORIAL TO THE NOBILITY OF SCOTLAND, Who are to Assemble in order to Choose the Sitting PEERS for the PARLIAMENT of Great Britain.
EDINBURGH, Printed by the Heirs and Successors of Andrew Anderson, Printer to the Queens most Excellent Majesty, Anno DOM, 1708.

DIV1.HEAD: A MEMORIAL TO THE NOBILITY OF SCOTLAND, &c.
DIV1.P: IF Heaven shall be pleased to open your Ears to the Humble and Sincere Application made to you in these Sheets in behalf of this miserably Divided Nation; your Lordships will let it be no Obstruction to the Benefit you may receive from it, that it comes from an Unknown or Inferiour Hand.

Let the Author be who he will, or what he will, your Lordships will be obliged to allow him to be a Friend to your Persons, to Truth, and to the Interest of Scotland, since no Man can be a Friend to either, that does not to his utmost pursue the great End proposed here, which is the publick Good and Peace of this Countrey.

This Paper is Address'd to your Lordships in your Double Capa∣city, 1. As Noblemen of Scotland. 2. As Peers of Britain▪ As the first, 'tis presumed you are all Inspired with Compassion for your Native Countrey, with Zeal for her Interest, with Concern for her Misfortunes, and with sincere affectionate Desires for her Recove∣ry.

As Peers of Britain, you are Embark'd in the general Good of the United Kingdom, you have her whole Politick Constitution and Capacity upon your Heads, are equally Patriots for one Part as for the other.

It is no matter who were for, or against the Union, that comes not in Consideration now, whoever was against it, or whoever was for it; you are all now equally concerned to keep it Sacred, and to make it an Advantage, which, without yoar Lordships Concurrence can never be done.

It would be a Charge too heavy, and what these Sheets shall not so much as suggest of such Honourable Persons as your Lordships, tha any of your Body should retain such Aversions to the Union, as to endeavour to make it produce all the Evils they formerly predicted of it.

Time, My Lords, and Gods Providence has already concurred to make the Union a mean of Deliverance to Scotland, and it is very remarkable that God has brought this Nation to a kind of a Necessity of giving Him publick Thanks for the UNION; the Thanksgiving on the third of June being in its Nature no less, as it was a Thanks∣giving for a Mercy received by the Agency of that Nation you are United to, and Effected as a Consequence of the Union, by virtue of which only England became obliged at their own Expence to rescue you out of the Hands of Popery and Tyranny, from which it is manifest Scotland could by no means have Delivered her self.

Those that say this Merits no Thanks either to England, or to the Union, and renounce the Obligation or Sense of Kindness, because England, had been obliged to do it for her own Safety, seem like the Ungratful Wretch, that when his House was on Fire, would give no Thanks to his Neighbour that put it out, because his own Interest obliged him to do it, to save his own House which was next.

It is out of Doubt that the Care and Concern England shew'd for the Danger of Scotland on this Occasion was an Effect of the Union, and therefore your Thanksgiving for the seasonable Deliverance you received is in one Sence, a giving Thanks for the Union—; And may Heaven go on to give this Nation constant Occasion to give Him Praise for the Effects of the Union, till in meer Sense of their own Interest they are entirely Reconciled to it as the only Mean, under God, of the Nations Safety and Prosperity—. But this by the way.

But in order to bring the Design of this Paper down to your Lordships immediate Contemplation, your Lordships are most humbly intreated to look a little into, and consider the present State of your Native Countrey, and perhaps by this your Lordships may be helped to see how much it is in your Lordships Power, and must of Necessity be your undoubted Duty to promote its Settlement and Prosperi∣ty.

Scotland, My Lords, Promised her self, and many of your Lord∣ships in your Thoughts Promised your selves for her a great many Advantages from the Union; It would be an unpleasant Contem∣plation to offer to your Lordships, that the Disappointment of all the good Things Scotland might Expect from the Union should ly at the Door of her Nobility, the Sons of her Triumph, which are her Boast and her Glory, some of whom were the very Means of making this very Union, and without whom it had never been brought to Perfection.

And yet so it is, and so it will appear to be, unless your Lordships shall in time Consider the State of your Countrey, listen to its Groans, hear the Voice of its Circumstances, and immediately Apply your selves to the proper Remedies.

We were told indeed one thing against the Union, which it is but too apparent proves True, tho' differently from the Thoughts of those that Suggested it, viz. That we should be Insected with the Contagion of Englands Vices, and so if we should partake of her Wealth, we should also partake of her Crimes.

Thus far this is come to pass, to the inexpressible Grief of all good Men, that we have been and are affected with the Contagion of
Englands Divisions, the Poyson of Partie Strife is already spread from thence upon us; and if your Lordships do not apply your selves to an immediat cure for this Mallady, the Leprosie of Bibery and Corrupti∣on will get into the Walls of the Building, and will never be cured till the very House (I mean the Constitution) be pull'd down to the very Foundation.

To explain this, it is necessary to enter a little into the Causes and Nature of our present Politicks, and see if the evil Spirit that is gone out among us, be not a Spirit of Destruction, and that aims at all sorts of National Confusions.

From whence come Strife and Divisions among you, says the Text, come they not from your Lusts? Lust of Rule, Lust of Ambition, Pride and Covetousness; are not these the Ground of our fatal Divisions; and how unhappy is it to see this Strife nowhere so fixt, as among our Nooles, who are the Guardians of our Peace, and should be the Dis∣couragers of all our Divisions.

It is in vain to flatter your Lordships Characters, and pay Homage to your Titles; but to speak plain, is to speak honestly, if these wretch∣ed Divisions begin among the Nobility, and from thence spread over this Nation, the Nobility then will have the Fame, (if such it can be counted,) of being their Countrys destroyers.

For GOD's sake then my Lords, and for your Countrys sake, for the sake of your Families, your Religion and your Posterity be pleas∣ed but to look into the present State of the Divisions of your Countrey, and when you do this Impartially; if you do not see, that you alone are the Cause of all this Distraction, you will at least see, that it is in your Power alone to cure it: And how your Lordships will answer it to your Honour, to your Consciences, to your Sons, and to your MAKER; That having it in your Power to save your Countrey from these miserable Confusions you neglected it, is enough to make you tremble to think on.

Among the Illustrious Appearance that are now to assem∣ble, a great many are come from England; what Spirit they carried up, and what they bring down, is very melancholly to reflect on; They went up united, they come down divided; They went up with Zeal and Love to their Countrey which they had united, they come
down possest with Party. D—'Is that was against their Countrys Peace; They went up uniting this Kingdom with its Neighbours, they come down dividing it against it self—: What my Lords has England done to you, or what have you done to one another? Where is the Spirit and the Zeal with which the Union was carried on here amids the Clamours of your Common Enemy? And what Condition shall this Countrey be in to defend it self against the Powerful Enemies of the Union both at Home and Abroad, if our Nobility who were the Life and Soul of the Union forsake the very first Principle of Union in Ge∣neral, viz. to unite one with another.

When your Lordships were fixing and finishing the great Affair of the Union, what noble Speeches came from your Mouths! And well we hoped, my Lords, they came from your Hearts, encouraging Uni∣on, perswading the People to imbrace Union, applauding Union it self as a Vertue, and the Union of Britain as an Honour and Advan∣tage: Is it possible the same Age that saw your Lordships so Zealous for Union, should see the same Noble Advocats of Peace divided into formidable Squadrons, fighting with the worst sort of Weapons against their Country? For all sorts of Divisions among your Lordships, are Wars raised against your Countreys Good.

And how weak are the Pretences of this Party-Struggle, and what is aim'd at in the Strife? The Good of our Countrey, as it is the specious Pretence of all publick Actions, so is it here: But will your Lordships be pleased to consider, The publick Good is always to be pursued by proper and suitable Methods. Peace is attained best in peaceable Methods. Pax quaeritur Bello is a Motto fit for Men in Arms; but in Councils, in Government, in Parliaments, it is the Men of Peace only, and Methods of Peace that can produce Peace. Where there is Strife and Contention, there is every evil Work: And it is impossible such Confusions of Interests, and Jarring of Parties as is now seen among us, can procure Peace, or be for the Countreys Good.

If it were sufficient to say we aim'd at the publick Good, then all Actions would be sanctified by that Cover: Even the French Invasion, my Lords, was so for the publick Good; and the worst Baits the De∣vil
lays to innare Men and Nations, are gilded over with that glitter∣ing Shew.

But, my Lords, will your Lordships be pleased to listen to a yet supe∣rior Instructor, whose Words have hitherto been Oracles to this whole Island: When Her Majesty pass'd the Bill for an Union of the two Kingdoms, you have Her Royal Instructions to all Her loving Subjects, to Unite with one another, as the only Bond of Peace, and as the only Safety and Happiness of the Na∣tion.

But from general Exhortations to Peace, your Lordships are in∣treated to look into the scandalous Trifles which are the Subject of the present Division, viz. Who shall or shall not be sent up to serve their Countrey in Parliament. And, in this Case, my Lords, it is most just to call it Scandalous and a Trifle.

Not that it is a Trifle, the sending Good, and Wise, and Honest Members to Parliament; But, my Lords, it is but a Trifle of Diffe∣rence, which Party those Good, Wise and Honest Men shall be chosen out of; especially if we compare the Thing with the terrible Divisi∣on it is now setting on Foot in this Nation.

And as for being Scandalous, ti's hoped your Lordships will pardon the Courseness of the Term, since it is impossible to give it any other that would be apposite and suited to the thing, while it gives but too just Ground to the People to suggest. That there must be some other End, than the mee Serving Scotland, in the eager Desire which ap∣pears in some Gentlemen, to be chosen for her Representatives. It is a most undoubted Truth, and your Lordships will bear with the Plain∣ness of Laying it down.

That whoever he is, that seeks or endeavours to be Elected a Mem∣ber of Parliament, whether Peer or Commoner, for any other Rea∣son, or with any other Design, than the Service and Good of his Countrey, so far betrays his Countrey, and the Trust reposed in him by his Countrey.

It is a most scandalous Reflection upon the Honour and Character of your Lordships, and all the Representative Body of Scotland, let them be of what Squadron they will, That it should be suggested, any Men, or Party of Men among your Illustrious Body, should have any
private Ends to seek in the honest Pursuit now made, of being Elected.

It cannot but be your Lordships Concern, therefore, to shew your Resentment at such ill Treatment, and at its Authors: But above all, to clear your Conduct from so much as the Shadow of such a Crime—, Not, my Lords, that it is a Crime to serve your Prince, but 'tis a Crime of the worst Nature, to seek to obtain what should be only the Reward of your Merit and Capacities, from a certain formidable Ap∣pearance, made by Strength of Party, not Merit; as if this or that Party had such or such a superior Influence on their Countrey, and therefore the Men must be imploy'd, lest they should &c.—

My Lords, this Paper forbears to enter into the unhappy Et Cetera's of this Argument, lest the Nakedness of some Mens Conduct should appear; which, in Hopes of their Amendment, and in Concern for their Reputation, are concealed.

If, my Lords, there are such pernicious Politicks now on Foot a∣mong you, and Men are forming themselves into Parties, in Affairs of this Moment, in order to get themselves into, or to keep them∣selves in Preferment, Imployments and Trusts in the publick Ad∣ministration; 'Tis a sad Token of their wanting Principles to discharge those Imployments, when they so far mortgage their Principles to obtain them.

For what Coherence, my Lords, have Places and Preferments, Pensions and Salaries under the Crown, or Advancement at Court, with Representing your Countrey in Parliament? It is true, we have a Court and a Queen that will not bribe her Subjects, to betray their Coun∣trey, nor suffer them to do it when they would; but it has not always been so, nor may it ever be so, and therefore it has been a long Struggle in the Parliament of England, to render Employment from the Court and Representatives in Parliament, inconsistent with one another—. But be that as it will, this is certain, tho they may have an honest Cohe∣rence with one another, they can have no honest Dependance upon one another. And therefore it is a most unsufferable Slander on your Lordships, to say that this Struggle is with any Design of serving your selves, or of recommending this or that Party to the Government, as of Superior Interest in Scotland; if this were your Design, it would brand
your Lordships Characters and Families with a Crime too infamous to name, nay it wold reproach the Queen her self and her Administrati∣on, as if her Majesty would be aw'd to bestow her Favours, or commit her Trust to ANY PARTY that appears formidable enough to carry the Election among the Peers.

Far be it from the Design of this Paper to suggest such a thing of so Honourable, so Illustrious a Body as the Nobility of Scotland, it cannot be, that a Thought so mean either of her Majesty or of her Admini∣stration, can enter into your Hearts, and if it should, you may be told without any Indecency, and much more without pretending to prophe∣cie that your Lordships will be mistaken.

Her Majesty has all along shewed in the placing and displacing Men and Partys such a steadiness of Resolution, and such a clearness of Judg∣ment, that it is not to be feared on one hand, or hoped on the other, that appearance of Faces only shall be a Key to her Favours, or Num∣bers of Names, and Strength of Party open or shut the Door to the Pow∣er of Administration: And therefore any Man whose Eyes are in his head, may acquaint your Lordships that this is not the way to obtain that End.

But my Lords, it cannot be unseasonable to remind your Lordships how publickly such Slanders are raised, how industriously spread, and how openly your Lordships Honour is insulted with such things as these, as if the gaining Places and Imployments at Court were the only thing, aimed at, and it must be wholsom Advice to your Lordships, let it come from never so mean a hand, that your Lordships would be pleas∣ed so to guard your Conduct, as to give no room for such vile Suggesti∣ons, that Posterity may know the Nobility of Scotland are not capable of any thing so low, so mean, so much under their Dignity and Chara∣cter in the World.

My Lords, the Nobility of Scotland never wanted Merit to recom∣mend them to their Princes Service, and to advance them both at Home▪ and Abroad; and to form Parties to obtain Places at the Price of the dividing and subdividing their Countrey, is a thing so mean, that it first supposes they wanted Merit otherways to recommend them, or that their Sovereign dispensed her Favours by appeareance, and un∣der the Aw of Parties, and not by the light of her Judgment, and the Merit of the Persons.

It is no hard matter my Lords to propose a general Unity and Con∣cord in this great Matter now before your Lordships, as the only way to preserve your Lordships and your Countrey from Ruine; but it is harder to propose a particular Method how to crush this Monster, this Infant Hydra, this wicked Spirit of Party-making just now crept into this Kingdom—. It is called a Spirit now crept in; not that the World is ignorant of your former Divisions which in their Degree have been pernitious enough, but the present Flood of ill Practices which is broke in upon the Nations Peace, is but new, and may re∣ceive a Check from your Lordships, if it be taken now before the Breach, at which it comes in, grows too wide to be made up.

The Design however of this Address is not to croud your Thoughts with Schemes of Elections, and form uniting Projects among your Lord∣ships, if your Eyes were open to the dangerous Consequence of the present Divisions, you would always apply your selves to the proper re∣medies, without any bodies Advice. Could you but see how this Me∣thod assures you of the certainty of their planting eternal Feuds and Animosities among you as a Nation, and among your Families as No∣blemen or Gentlemen, ever rivalling, ever undermining one another, could you be made sensible of the Consequences of these things to your Children and to the Government, how by strength of Parties some of the Nobility may for ever be excluded from the Honour of sitting in Parliament, a Priviledge born with them, and which they may have done nothing to forefeit; how this will rouze the retired Families of the Nobility, and make them ever be pushing at, and forming Parties for Elections, and how it will entail Family Grudge, personal Peike, and Party-quarrels on our Posterity, handing down Mischief, and convey∣ing rancour'd Blood from Generation to Generation, when your Lord∣ships Eyes are open to these things, and you shall come but to give your selves leisure to consider them, your Lordships might be left to find out the easy Remedy for such fatal Mischiefs, you could not but apply your selves to it, for they are really Mines filled with all manner of Combustibles, ust ready to be sprung, and to blow up the very Foun∣dation of this Nations Felicity.

And now my Lords, not to enter upon Methods of Election, or al∣tering the Scheme directed by Parliament, yet 'tis humbly left upon your Lordships Thoughts to consider of as a Medium to preserve your Lord∣ships and your Posterity in Peace and Amity among your selves, and prevent the mortal Contagion of Party-strife spreading it self over this Nation, to the Ruine of your Honour, your Peace, and your Posterity, whether this Election might not be carried on without the Breach a∣mong your Lordships, which all Wise Men foresee, and all Good Men are grieved for.

Ballot has been thought of as a Medium to prevent the particular Peikes and Feuds, which from the various Sidings of Families and Inte∣rests may be too frequent among the Nobility, since in the Balloting it cannot be known (other than Men will discover themselves) who any Man gives his Vote for: But then again this will not at all put a stop to the Sollicitations and Struggle of Parties among us, which is the Root of all the other Mischiefs, and will be always a teeming Brooder of unforeseen Evils among us.

Rotation has been rejected in Parliament, and as it would be a Me∣thod to which your Lordships would be tied down by Law, and from which you could upon no Consideration whatever recede, it is not without its Inconveniences, and is not altogether consistent with the Nature of a Free Representative.

But might it not be worth your Lordships while to consider, whe∣ther such a thing as a voluntar Rotation might not be form'd by Con∣sent, and in time obtain by Custom, so as to be the receiv'd Method of Elections, reserving still the Right of breaking in upon it, tho not to practise it but in extraordinary Cases—. This my Lords is a sort proposal, but it is full of various Advantages to your Countrey, to the Nobility as a Body, and to the particular Families of the Nobility as Peers, and it will be very difficult to find out one Inconvenience that can be charged upon it, Nor can any thing be objected against it, but that perhaps your Lordships will say the Proposal comes too late, and it is otherways determined.

1. My Lords, by this method all the Nobility in Scotland who are legally qualified, will, or may if they please, enjoy their Right
of sitting in Parliament, and so the Union not be reproacht with taking away their Birth-right.

2. Your Lordships will be made Judges among your selves of personal Merit, and may reject any Nobleman who has rendred himself unworthy of the Honour of representing you; and tho upon none but extraordinary Occasions, such Distinctions will be made, yet your Lordships would be Judges of these Extraordi∣nary Occasions.

3.This unhappy Party-struggle among you would immediatly die, and be forgotten, you would have no more Squadrons of Parties formed against one another, labouring to engross the Votes of their Inferiors, to purchase the Smiles of their Superi∣or, all the Bribery and Corruption, which if it be not yet come in, will of course follow these Proceedings, must of course be left off; all the Fury of Parties will die, the Fire of Contention go out, and the Nobility of Scotland will be delivered from a new In∣fection; which if it be once spread among them, will in time de∣bauch their Principles, and render their Persons contemptible.
The World, my Lords, is not without Examples of this kind; and tho many might be produced, yet two are so Eminent, and so near your Lordships, that they will be most familiar to your Thoughts.

The Parliaments of England, of Scotland, and of Britain now, (by Consequence of the Union) have an undoubted Right to limit the Suc∣cession, and transpose the Right of Ascending to the Throne of this Island; and this being established in both Kingdoms in their separate State by particular Declarations, besides Precedents, it may pass for a Maxim here, without requiring further Confirmation.

Now, tho the several Qualifications which the Law requires, may incapacitat any person to govern, who otherways had the Right of primogeniture▪ as in the Case of the Abdication of the late King and the descending to his Children being both suspected, and also Popish; and tho' the Parliament have an absolute power to declare and determine this or that person to be Successor or Heir apparent; yet when Circumstances have put them off from one Branch or another, they have always kept the Line in view, and still reserving the Right of naming the Succes∣sor,
they have always gone to the next in Blood, against whom no le∣gal Exception has lyen.

A second Instance is in the Election of the Lord Mayor of the City of London, which is thus, the Common Hall, that is, the Suffrages of all the Livery-men or Burgesses of the City, is required to choose two Men out of the Court of Aldermen to be Lord Mayor; these when by the Majority of the Electors they are chosen, are returned to the Court of Aldermen.

The Court of Aldermen is obliged to name one of these two as Lord Mayor for the Year ensuing, it is absolutely in the Breast of the Alder∣men to take which of the two they please; and sometimes as they see occasion, they do break into their Custom, and choose out of their usual Method, but generally speaking, and unless some extraordinary Case interveen, they choose the Senior Alderman, or as they call it, he that is next the Chair.

Both these examples its presumed are exactly to the Case—, and prove that the Nobility of Scotland may in this Election observe a volun∣tary Rotation, and take their whole Body in its Course, either begin∣ning at the Eldest or Highest, down to the Youngest or Lowest of the Nobility, or one of the Highest, one of the lowest; and yet ly under no other Obligation to confine themselves to it than the Court of Alder∣men do in choosing the person next the Chair.

If any Nobleman by reason of his Circumstances, either of Health or Estate, found it not for his Convenience, his Absence from the Assem∣bly might determine it, since it were easy to resolve to choose none but such as were present, or such as sent their Names, desiring to be esteemed as present.

O how would this at one Blow overwhelm all the Schemes and Pro∣jects of the present Squadrons of Separation! how would it remove all the ill Blood the Poison and Rancor that is breaking in upon Families. How would it establish the Peace and Tranquillity of the Nobility of Scotland, which by the other unhappy Divisions now on foot is like to be perfectly destroyed and trampled under foot, even by its own Mem∣bers. But alas! We are told already 'tis too late, the War is begun, and no such Capitulation (the worse for Scotland still) can be hearkened to.

There is another Method, but what hopes is there to see it put in practice! and what a happy, Nation would we be, if it could be brought to pass! And this is that laying aside Parties and privat Designs! the Nobility of Scotland would act like themselves, and make their Ele∣ction intirely free from any remote View of Interest or Prejudices, and choosing Men of Capacity and Merit, as well as Nobility of Birth, seek to raise and maintain the Reputation of Scotland in the House of Peers, rather than the Reputation of Party, in the hopes of a share in the Spoils of the Nation.

This would bring the Members of Scotland in either House into a Fi∣gure suited to the Trust their Countrey has reposed in them, and this it is not too late to do. But my Lords, when all is carried by Interest and Party, Club and Cabal, when Whigs set up Torries against Whigs, and Tor∣ries set up Whigs against Torries, what can this be? is this a Strife for your Nation! is this a Struggle for the publick Good! is it not a meer Strife for Mastery, and the Heavings of two Mighty Parties, who push their secret Designs, and have something else besides the Good of Scot∣land in their Vew?

And what will be the Consequences of these things? GOD Almigh∣ty only knows what National Mischiefs His Goodness will prevent, which would otherways be the Effect of such Division▪ but it would be very satisfactory to many that wish well to Scotland, ome body that sees farther than ordinary into such things would clear up some of these Doubts about them.

1 st. Whether this will not in its nature tend, Not breaking or intirely dissolving the Nobility of Scotland as a Body that can hardly be possible, tho the Scripture says, A House against it self cannot stand: But to the lessening their Characters, rendring them contemptible in the Eyes of the World, and particularly of Honest Men; as men who have abandoned all Concern for their Countrey, are acted only by their Private Interests, and Pursue▪ nothing but the Game of Preferment and Partys, and by Consequence are not to be valued, trusted, or depended upon.

2. Whether this will not oblige the Queen in meer Defence of her Majesties Character as to discerning, and to let her Subjects know, that Names, Numbers, and a shew of Party-Strength, cannot aw or
byass her Judgment in the Choice of her Servants, to contemn all Parties that so openly pursue such a Game, under Colour of the Ser∣vice of their Countrey, & resolve to imploy NONE of them, be their fancied Success never so great, except such as their personal Merit and different Conduct shall recommend: And if her Majesty has ta∣ken up such Resolutions already, whether all the World does not ju∣stifie her Royal Prudence in it, and applaud both her Majesties Wis∣dom and Resolution.

3. Whether the Animosities this Party-Struggle lays the Foundati∣on of, and which it is, apparent will be at least triennally renewed, do not weaken Scotland in particular, lay her open to Foreign Ene∣mies, disable her People in the general Defence of the Government, and may not in time be run up to such a height as may be dangerous to the publick Peace—; and thus she shall be rendered contemp∣tible on one hand, and suspected on the other, and be constantly bjected to the insult of a Foreign Enemie, that would gladly over∣hesm both Parties.

Thus my Lords, not the Ruine of your own Characters, the blasting the Honour of the Nobility of Scotland, and rendring even the Repre∣sentatives ou shall choose contemptible in the Eyes of the World; not th the exposing your Countrey to eternal Feud, Division and , and perhaps at last to Destruction, may be in the Womb of this present Contention—. And it cannot be doubted, but if your ordships will be to take these things into your serious Conside∣ration, yo upon some Method at the approaching Meeting of the Nobi vent the Mischiefs which such Party-making and Di∣viding with.
